Tulane University • Mathematics

Mahir Bilen Can

I am a professor of mathematics at Tulane University. My research explores the interface of algebraic structures, representation theory, and geometry, with applications ranging from error-correcting codes to secure communication.

Research

Themes & directions

See full CV

Algebraic groups and monoids

Research

Structure, classification, and geometric properties, with applications to representation theory and combinatorics.

  • Reductive groups
  • Invariant theory
  • Symmetric varieties

Representation theory

Research

Interactions between representations, geometry, and number theory—especially where symmetry clarifies complex systems.

  • Unitary representations
  • Harmonic analysis
  • Category-theoretic tools

Algebraic geometry

Research

Geometric methods for understanding algebraic structures and moduli, connecting geometry with computational techniques.

  • Singularities
  • Compactifications
  • Birational geometry

Error-correcting codes & secure communication

Research

Algebraic and geometric approaches to robust communication, coding theory, and cryptographic protocols.

  • Classical & quantum codes
  • Post-quantum security
  • Information theory

Laboratory

QSPARC Lab

QSPARC is a research initiative at Tulane University focused on advancing secure communication systems through algebraic methods, coding theory, and experimentation. Current work includes post-quantum cryptographic protocols, algebraic and geometric constructions of error-correcting codes, and hands-on testing with SDR radios. The lab is a collaborative hub for student research and interdisciplinary exploration.
